title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Ep. 40 - What Gets Your Moving? (ft. Carly Musser)
description: Carly Musser, and Exercise Physiologist and Mental Performance Consultant, joins The Wellfocused Podcast to discuss the motivation behind exercise. We dive into how motivation varies person to person, what types of motivation are most effective, and the importance of finding your "why".
author: Mitch Sherman

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Ep. 15 - Leadership and Innovation (ft. Roy Rosin)
description: The Wellfocused Podcast welcomes Roy Rosin, Chief Innovation Officer at Penn Medicine. Roy shares his perspective on what innovation means to him and what draws him to his position. Additionally, Roy discusses how he views leadership, what he learned from his mentors, and how to factor in the human element into making organizations work.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Ep. 40 - Proper Pronoun-ing (ft. Jessica Cooper)
description: Social Worker Jessica Cooper joins The Wellfocused Podcast to discuss the ins and outs of modern day pronoun usage. We discuss how and why it is important to use pronounce correctly, societal influence, and why it is vital to respect someone's identity.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Ep. 38 - Is Sitting The New Smoking?
description: On this episode of The Wellfocused Podcast, I dissect a couple research articles that tackle the ever-growing question: Is Sitting The New Smoking? With an increase in remote work as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is important to consider the risks that come with excessive sitting. However, is this more dangerous than smoking, as this trendy question seems to imply?
author: Mitch Sherman

title: Reading List from The Office of Inclusion and Diversity
description: Reading List from The Office of Inclusion and Diversity
author: Penn Medicine. Office of Inclusion and Diversity

title: Lindsay Bowler - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
If there’s a need for change, and we have a vision for it, my team is encouraged to do it. We’re not deterred by challenges or bumps in the road.  


Setting up equipment for a CPR class with my supervisor, we looked across the room and saw a sea of light-skinned manikins. Around the same time, our colleague pointed out that the infusion manikins were almost exclusively light-skinned.   


After identifying this opportunity for growth in our department, we started the process of purchasing more training equipment and manikins with multiple different skin tones. Now when we meet with vendors, one of the first questions we ask is about diversity and inclusion, both in their products and in their practices as an organization. It can be hard to find training equipment and manikins that are not light-skinned, but we’re starting to see our vendors make strides toward providing more diverse options.   


I never want someone to feel unwelcome when they walk into one of our trainings. Nor do I want providers to have gaps in their training because they’ve only worked with manikins representing light-skinned patients.  


Our patients and our clinicians come from many different racial, ethnic, and cultural backgrounds, and our equipment, tools, and training gear should reflect the population we serve.  


Changing the way we do things isn’t always easy, but it’s the right thing to do.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Tanira Butcher - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
When I’m with a patient, it’s like I’m their family member for the day.  

My patient was an elderly woman who had late-stage cancer. When I got to her room, I heard from the nurses that she had not slept well. Like many people with dementia, she had her days and nights confused and was restless. I started by giving her a bath because sometimes that helps people wake up. She was a little bit agitated, so I thought about how I could make her feel more comfortable.  

The only real barrier between us was language — I don’t speak any Vietnamese, Thai, or Arabic, which were my patient’s languages, and she didn’t speak any English. We had tried using the interpreter service, but my patient wasn’t really engaging with it.  

 I decided to look for Thai music to play on my phone for her. I saw that the music soothed her, and she sat up in bed and let me hold her hand. She even seemed to be singing along with it.  

 Later that day, a friend of my patient came to visit her. She told me my patient was actually saying her prayers, not singing. I looked up Thai prayers and began playing those on my phone. Our culture, our beliefs are so important to who we are, and it really helped me to care for my patient when I learned more about her.  

 After her friend left, I brought out a basket of clean towels and told her that I’d washed some clothes and needed help folding them. She folded up the towels, then I put them in a pile and quietly moved them back to the basket so she could fold them again. Everyone folds laundry, and I wanted her to feel like she was doing something normal that she would do in her daily life.  

It’s like I was hanging out with my grandma — she just speaks a different language than I do.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 4, Ep. 7 - Social Determinants of Health (ft. Winter Wiggins)
description: Winter Wiggins, Employee Program Specialist & Care Navigator, joins the Wellfocused Podcast to discuss Project Thrive and social determinants of health. Often times, the reasons behind our health issues are more than meets the eye. Here, we discuss how our socioeconomic standing can determine our health outcomes.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: ABC123: A Cheatsheet for a Calm Thanksgiving
description:
Keep this simple exercise in mind this holiday season when you inevitably find yourself in need of a good dose of calm. Whether it's the time your in-laws comment on your cooking skills, when you find the kids scrawling their latest masterpiece across the basement walls, or when you remember the person missing from the holiday table, keep in mind: ABC123


A: Awareness. Notice your body, hands, legs, feet. Orient to who you are, where you are, what day it is, and the time

B: Breath. Draw in 3 long, slow, comfortable deep breaths. Prolong the exhale

C: Count. Identify 3 things you can see, you can hear, you can feel, you can smell, you can taste

1. One Thing. What is the 1 next thing for you to do right now?

2. Two Strengths. What are 2 strengths you can draw on right now? (These may be internal strengths or external resources)

3. Three Thanks. What are 3 things you are grateful for right now? (these may be small or large)
author: Dr. Rachel Kishton

title: What is Brain Fog?
description: Have you been feeling disorganized, mentally sluggish, and unable to remember things as well as you used to? If you are struggling to concentrate or pay attention, you might be struggling with brain fog. In this podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety, will discuss symptoms of brain fog and what you can do about them. This will serve useful for anyone looking to optimize their mental clarity and boost their well-being and productivity amidst this ongoing pandemic and beyond.
author: Dr. Lily Brown

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 10 - How Do You Talk to Yourself? (ft. Dr. Lily Brown)
description: Dr. Lily Brown, Director at the Center for the Treatment and Study of Anxiety at the University of Pennsylvania, joins The Wellfocused Podcast to discuss self-talk. Self-talk is something we all participate in and depending if you talk to yourself positively or negatively, can significantly affect your wellbeing. Listen in and learn about positive ways to enhance your self-talk.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: Danine T. Jones - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
I like to make things personal with people.  


When I have a new patient, I come into their room and I say, “Hi, I’m Dee with food services. Any questions about the menu?”  In some cases, I use hand gestures to help them understand me, making a motion with my hand going to my mouth. Then I look for the reaction on their face. When there’s a language barrier, sometimes I look for a picture of a type of food on my phone to show them, or use the interpreter service if we need extra support.  


It feels good to have food options for patients, and I always offer those small choices to them. I say, “do you want apple juice, orange juice, tea, or coffee?” It helps them get back to normal, and to feel like a whole person again. That’s such an important part of healing. I find out what comfort foods they like, and try to provide them so they feel more like themselves.  


One man came back to the hospital for a surgery after another visit several months before. I asked him if he still liked his chocolate pudding. I remember what my patients like, I remember what they don’t like, so they know I’m here for them.  


I really care about people, and I want them to know I have their back while they’re at the hospital. I’m also rooting for them to get well so they can return to their normal lives. The way I look at it – we’re in a relationship together, we’re on this road together, and that’s comforting.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 4, Ep. 3 - Live Mailbag Episode(ft. Janna Rothschild and Emily McPeak)
description: The Wellfocused team is back for its third mailbag episode of The Wellfocused Podcast! This time, we recorded this live with an audience of UPHS employees submitting questions pertaining to general health and wellbeing.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 4, Ep. 6 - DEI from an LGBTQ+ Perspective (ft. Kyle Bonner)
description: Kyle Bonner, LCSW, Coordinator of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion, joins The Wellfocused Podcast to discuss societal changes from the perspective of the LGBTQ+ community. Here, we address the state of DEI in society as well as the reaction to the simultaneous progression and regression of inclusion in the country.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: Sleep Tips
description: Over the last year, the prevalence of sleep disorders and insomnia have increased tremendously. In this podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety, walks you through a few brief sleep tips. Dr. Brown shares evidence-based practices that you can use as first steps to tackle clinically significant insomnia. This podcast shares some great reminders for everyone who is trying to improve their sleep schedules and sleeping habits this year.
author: Dr. Lily Brown

title: Lars Peterson - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
I started working at the coffee cart at the entrance of Pennsylvania Hospital (PAH) 12 years ago. I loved being one of the first people to greet patients and their families when they walked in the door. The way I saw it, my role was to help create an environment in which everyone feels welcome.  




 Several years later, I was able to apply my hospitality skills to a new role in Patient and Guest Relations, and I am still one of the first faces people see. As patient experience coordinator, I work closely with patients, providers, and administrators to ensure our patients get the best possible care. There are times when our patients don’t feel understood. I’m fortunate that in my role I get to listen to patients, find out what their needs are, and then communicate those needs to staff. Sometimes it’s as simple as going to get a breast pump for a new parent or working with a translator to discuss a patient’s options for care.  




Making people feel welcome is vital to establishing trust and providing equitable care. One way to build trust is to expand our connections in the community. Working alongside a team at PAH, I helped create a pathway program that partnered with two local charter schools. This year, we hired 10 high school graduates from the class of 2022 who are interested in health care careers and want to attend college using the UPHS tuition assistance benefit.  




The students rotate through multiple departments during their four-month paid internship. After the rotation ends, each student is matched with the department that’s the right fit for them and continues as full-time staff.  




 In addition to providing employment, we offer mentorship in the health care field. In one case, we had a patient services associate who wanted to become a phlebotomist. We paired her with the director of the laboratory so she could find out what classes to take and ask questions about the job she was pursuing.  




 The idea is to bring students in before they’ve made career choices and let them know what’s possible. It’s one small way to broaden our reach and help all who walk through our doors feel welcome.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Taryn Pettigrew - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
Hair is so important to our identity, especially when many things from a person’s normal life have been stripped away by illness or injury.  

 As occupational therapists (OTs), we remind people that they are whole, they are capable, and that we want them to get back to all the activities that allow them to feel like themselves again. One patient encounter really hit home this point and emphasized to me how important it is for us to be able to meet the needs of all the patients we see.  

I was doing rounds, and I was talking to a woman who was the patient of another OT. She pulled me aside and asked if I would be able to wash her hair, but I had to get to another patient. I went out into the hall and found a nurse whose hair was textured in a similar way to mine and the patient’s, and she said she would help wash her hair. As the three of us were talking and laughing together, I could just see the woman’s face change as she recognized we were going to help her, we understood her, and we had her back.  

 The subject of hair care had come up before, and the Rehabilitation staff acknowledged that we needed better tools for styling all textures of hair. My supervisor Natalia asked me for recommendations for styling tools that would work with textured hair.  

 Natalia later told me, “I never imagined how looking at the hair combs we have available could spark a larger conversation about culture and race in our profession.” On our floor, we’ve been talking a lot more about how we serve all the patients in our community, and what we can do to make everyone feel understood and valued. We are continuing to search for hair products that work for all populations.  

 A hair comb might seem like a small detail, but it can play a large role in getting a person back to feeling like themselves again. As OTs, that’s what we want most for our patients.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Finding the Silver Lining...Or Not
description: Sometimes, it is not always ideal to find the silver linings in tough situations. In this video, the Wellfocused Team discusses the dynamics of toxic positivity and strategies to combat it to help pave your way to greater wellbeing.
author: Emily McPeak

title: Dr. Ben Cooperberg
description:
Sometimes the best way to treat a patient’s illness is to talk to them about something else.  

Recently I was talking to a new patient about her Type 2 diabetes. Her blood sugars were too high, and I was encouraging her to start insulin treatment. I told her about the treatment and shared statistics about the outcomes, but I could see that I wasn’t getting through. She seemed tuned out as I continued talking.  

Suddenly her gaze fell on my wedding ring. “Are those Hebrew letters?” she asked. I told her they come from the Song of Solomon: “I am to my beloved as my beloved is to me.” Her eyes softened, and she smiled at me as she shared, “That has always been my favorite Biblical poem!”  

She asked if I’m Jewish, and I said that I am. She told me she is very involved in her church, and draws strength from that community. For the rest of our time together, we chatted about religions and the ways in which they challenge and comfort us. I didn’t mention insulin again, but urged her to return to the clinic. She admitted that at first, she wasn’t planning to come back. But after our conversation, she was looking forward to her next visit.  

How someone feels is a big part of their health. We want to help people feel better, and help their health—those things go hand in hand. That day with my patient, I recognized that how she felt about me as a person was more important than whether she agreed to start a new treatment in that moment. We both benefitted from connecting—not as doctor and patient, but as two people.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Preparing for Emotional Chaos
description: Life is chaotic. In this short podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety, shares how you can invest in your emotional well-being in advance of the chaos to feel better prepared. Dr. Brown discusses the PLEASE tool that you can use to make note of what makes you vulnerable and build resilience in the face of stress. This podcast will be useful to anyone looking to support their emotional and mental health.
author: Lily Brown, PhD

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 9 - Exercise: A Game for All Ages
description: This episode of The Wellfocused Podcast addresses some common misconceptions pertaining to resistance training for children, as well as older populations. Tune in to learn about where these myths originated and why strength training is beneficial for everyone.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: What is the Best Diet for Your Mental Health?
description: In this second episode focusing on nutrition and mental health, registered dietitian Rachel Daddio discusses different diets and how they can affect mental health.  Rachel also discusses different vitamins and minerals and what roles they play in mental health.
author: Mind on Mental Health

title: Tender, Loving Self-Care for Asian Americans
description:
A guide for tending to the traumas of anti-Asian violence and racism.

Image Source: Le Minh Phuong/Unsplash
author: Due Quach

title: The Root of Anxiety During Covid-19: Masks not Yoga
description:
Q: I kind of resent being told to do yoga and mindfulness when the reason I can't sleep at night is being worried that there is insufficient PPE and I am going to kill my family. #masksnotyoga  I realize that isn't really a question but please get to the real root of our anxiety rather than putting a bandage on it and pretending you care.
A: We greatly appreciate your comments. As you note, the anxiety associated with this crisis is profound and based entirely in reality. The perceived “real root” of anxiety may differ for each of us—for you and many others it may be insufficient PPE that might lead to infecting family but for others it may be entirely different features of what the virus brings. The real root is ultimately the virus itself, and many, many others are working to contain it. We each contribute what we can, and the PennMedicineTogether effort simply hopes to offer resources and strategies for people who want help with the anxiety symptoms that this crisis has caused or exacerbated. This is not designed to encourage yoga or mindfulness but rather to offer strategies that help people cope, which we all do differently. If you can’t sleep and feel the degree of anxiety you describe, maybe there are other types of intervention that might help you feel a little bit better while we all wait for the “real root” to get addressed? Please do think about accessing one of our live support resources.
author: Jody Foster & Aliza Narva

title: Understanding Trauma
description: Join Dr. Lily Brown, Director of Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety as she discusses trauma and stressor-related disorders. Learn the impact of prolonged exposure, common responses, and ways to overcome it.
author: Lily Brown

title: Wellfocused Podcast: Season 1, Episode 5- Telehealth Takes-Off (ft. Alberto Pascucci)
description: This episode of The Wellfocused Podcast features Alberto Pascucci, a Physician Assistant in the Urology department at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. Alberto was instrumental in the development and execution of CHOP's teleheath program during the COVID-19 pandemic. He shares some benefits and obstacles of the growing presence of telehealth while also touching on some larger societal issues pertaining to health care.
author: Mitchell Sherman

title: Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 2, Ep. 1 - What is COBALT? (ft. Kelley Kugler)
description: On the season 2 premiere  of The Wellfocused Podcast, we are joined by Kelley Kugler, a Senior Innovation Manager at Penn and the Director of Cobalt. Kelley shares her insights on what Cobalt is, how it started, where its going, and its pivotal role in getting through the COVID-19 pandemic.
author: Mitchell Sherman

title: 5 Exercises To Calm Our Body's Stress Response
description: These simple exercises are designed to release oxytocin and thereby calm the nervous system and support resilience.
author: Linda Graham

title: Mental Health Minute Podcast
description: This is a podcast created with tips to manage anxiety during COVID-19.
author: Arshad Siddiqui, MD, Medical Director for Outpatient Psychiatry, Princeton House Behavioral Health

title: Beth, Laurie, and Jen - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
This story starts with a successful birth: mother and baby were thriving. About two weeks later, the new mom arrived in the emergency room at Lancaster General Hospital (LGH) with a breast abscess. The attending physician recommended a minor surgical procedure to drain the abscess, followed by antibiotics. After a brief conversation with the care team through an interpreter, she left the emergency room against the advice of the attending physician.  

 My name is Laurie Longenecker, and I’m a registered nurse in the Healthy Beginnings Plus program at LGH. We always work as a team to care for patients. Jen Snyder, Bethany Landgraff, and I collaborate to provide home health care, psychosocial and breastfeeding support, and many other services during home visits.  

As Jen puts it, “we learn so much about a person by visiting their home and learning about their life.” Before the baby was born, Jen spent a lot of time at the mother’s house helping her get the services she needed, including access to SNAP benefits to help feed her family.  

 Our team was notified about the mother’s emergency room visit. The next day at her home, I found her unable to sit up due to the pain in her breast. I knew that time was of the essence, but I also realized that I had to understand why she was resistant to treatment.  

 With the help of an interpreter, I carefully explained the recommended procedure. After a long conversation, the patient started to relax and seemed more open. She told me that when she first went to the emergency room, she thought the physician was saying she would have to have the whole breast removed. Now that I understood the new mom’s reservations, I was able to convince her to get the care she needed.  

 On a follow-up visit, Bethany discovered the patient hadn’t secured her course of antibiotics that were essential to her treatment. Bethany filled the prescription, helping to avoid another emergency room visit.  

 Jen, Bethany, and I continued to follow up with her for many weeks, often visiting her in her home. I’m happy to say that mom and baby are once again thriving. Bethany continues to follow up with our patient, providing lactation services and support for her and her infant. Our work is a team effort, for sure. They say it takes a village, and it really does.  

 We love working with parents, being welcomed into their homes, and learning about their lives. Ultimately, they are the experts on their own bodies and on their families. We’re here to provide support so they can get the best possible care for themselves and for their children.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 3 - Enough "Burnout" (ft. Lauren Hess)
description: Lauren Hess, Wellbeing Supervisor from our Lancaster General Health location, joins the podcast to discuss the ever present topic of burnout. We talk about what new strategies are being developed to combat burnout, what employees need, and fatigue of the concept itself.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: President Barack Obama's Recommended Reading List on Anti-Racism
description: Read President Barack Obama's Recommended Reading List on Anti-Racism on the site for CPUP's Committee on Anti-Racism.
author: Barack Obama

title: Coronavirus & Sleep: Intese Dreaming
description: For Image use image from article with Photo illustrator: Kay Scanlon / Los Angeles Times; Getty ImagesPeople have been having intense, vivid dreams about coronavirus. From contracting the illness themselves to having fears that their parents/loved ones will get sick. These dreams can be considered vivid nightmares and some involve metaphors of bugs resembling moments of hurt or injuries. This article explains why dreams are so vivid, most the time it's because if something vivid is happening in the outside world, it'll impact them in dreams.
author: Rachel Schnalzer

title: What Optimists Do Differently
description: This online course teaches you how to incorporate resilience interventions in your personal and professional lives. It will expose you to the foundational research of resilience including protective factors, such as mental agility and optimism.
author: Karen Reivich, PhD

title: How To Deal With Racism Or Unconscious Bias From Coworkers
description:
Regardless of whether diversity and inclusion programs are effective, you can be your own advocate and empower yourself in handling uncomfortable and demeaning encounters. So, how does one deal with racist or biased incidents?


For more resources from the Penn Medicine CPUP Anti-Racism Committee visit: https://www.med.upenn.edu/CPUPAntiRacism/resources.html
author: Brande Martin

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 4, Ep. 4 - Work Environment Stressors (ft. Jessie Jarmon)
description: Staff Support Specialist Jessie Jarmon, MSW, LCSW, joins the Wellfocused Podcast to discuss work environment stressors. Here, we dive into common trends that cause stress for people everyday at work and what strategies can be used to combat this stress.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: Productivity and Time Management
description: This article looks at productivity and time management - two things that are said to be distinct but actually interact with and affect each other more than we realize. In order to be more productive, time management is part of the problem. This is very relevant due to our remote work life right now, as often times it's hard to be as productive and manage our time effectively.
author: Adam Grant

title: Two Coping Skills You Can Teach Your Children
description: This podcast shares two DBT coping skills parents can teach their children to help them tolerate negative emotions and manage impulsivity.
author: Daina Haines, LCSW & Andy Dean, LCSW

title: Marchant Jackson and Lawrence Pratt- PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description: Stay tuned for the release of Marchant Jackson and Lawrence Pratt's story of Cultural Humility with The Penn Medicine Experience 2022.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Caring for the Caregiver During the Pandemic
description: This video is a guiding example for how to care for caregivers during the pandemic.  As the caregiver assumes the role of taking care of their loved ones or other individuals, their feelings/emotions often get lost - this video shows many different versions of caregivers and if they are from assisted care or family members. It helps share examples for how caregivers can find ways to focus on themselves in addition to those they are assisting.
author: Health Advocate

title: Guidelines of When It is Appropriate to Return to Work After Having Covid-19
description:
​Q: I read the CDC guideline about returning employee tested positive for COVID 19, it said that the employee can return after at least 7 days of feverless and no other symptoms. One of my colleague, just return to work after being tested positive, he did 12 days of isolation. The management did not communicate anything about is return with the other employees. Even if they are following the recommendations, it will be wise to share such information with the others who are putting they life on the line. the employee who returned is young (23 years old), others are more older with preexisting health conditions. The fact is that, the recommendations from the CDC are changing periodically as we advance in the situation. None of the experts on COVID 19 have made a clear statement about immunity that one may get from the disease and how long it may last. Even, about re-infestation, there is not much information. Thus, we should inform employees when one of them is returning after being positive for COVID 19 (without violating HIPAA) in order for some of them to express their concern and maybe leave because they are in the high risk of the mortality for COVID 19. Those employee should be protected when they leave. This may help reduce the fatality rate that have been projected. Sincerely, Thank you.

A: The current CDC and PA Department recommendations for healthcare workers retuning to work if they have had COVID-19 are that people need to be at least 7 days from symptom onset, with improving symptoms, and no fevers for 72 hours (and have not taken any medications to reduce the fever). This is based on what we know at present about viral shedding and infectivity after infection. Our occupational health and infection control teams discuss in person with each person returning to work to ensure it is safe to do so. While we are learning about the disease, this is expert guidance on balancing what we know about infectivity and healthcare workers essential to the workforce and patient care. Our priority is the health and safety of our staff and we are closely monitoring any new information available. Our goal is also to protect the privacy of our staff, and so we work behind the scenes and through your manager to ensure you have the information that is necessary for your safety. Our universal masking policy is also designed to help protect you at work. If you have specific concerns about your health status or underlying conditions that may pre-dispose you to more severe disease, please discuss with occupational health - we can help give individual guidance.
author: Kathleen M Murphy, MD, Assistant Professor of Clinical Medicine, Division of Infectious Diseases

title: Ways to be Resilient
description: Video-based tools to help build personal and professional resilience. The videos are added frequently and have different individuals contributing to resources and tips of how to be resilient. There are more than 20 videos in the library.
author: UPENN Positive Psychology

title: What Happened To MY World
description: 'What Happened to MY World?' is for parents, caregivers, and everyone working tohelp children and families make sense of a confusing, unpredictable, and sometimesviolent world. It is designed to help adults support children's fears, their grief, andtheir struggles to understand why 'whether through acts of nature or human beings' the ground under their feet can disappear and the world becomes a very frighteningplace. It is to help both those who experience and survive catastrophe firsthand aswell as the children who witness it from a distance and wonder what it was like orwhether they will find themselves in similar circumstances. Source: Jim Greenman
author: Jim Greenman - Bright Horizons Family Solutions

title: Meditation: In Depth
description: Meditation is a mind and body practice that has a long history of use for increasing calmness and physical relaxation, improving psychological balance, coping with illness, and enhancing overall health and well-being. Many studies have been conducted to look at how meditation may be helpful for a variety of conditions, such as high blood pressure, certain psychological disorders, and pain.

title: Enjoy Nature Responsibly
description: Spending time outdoors, with adjustments to how space is used, is a sustainable, proven approach to preserving mental health. Congregating in groups is no longer allowed, but spending time outside can still be a safe, practical way to buffer the loneliness, stress, and anxiety of new extreme social distancing measures.
author: Eugenia C. South, MD and Raina M. Merchant, MD

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 5 - Weight Management and Carb Dynamics (ft. Dr. Rameck Hunt)
description: Dr. Rameck Hunt joins the Wellfocused Podcast to discuss the ins and outs of how he approaches weight management programs. We dive into different aspects of carbohydrates, the importance of lifestyle changes, and how communication and education is pivotal to patient health.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: How to find the person who can help you get ahead at work
description: The workplace is often presented as a meritocracy, where you can succeed by putting your head down and working hard. Wall Street veteran Carla Harris learned early in her career that this a myth. The key to actually getting ahead? Get a sponsor: a person who will speak on your behalf in the top-level, closed-door meetings you're not invited to (yet). Learn how to identify and develop a productive sponsor relationship in this candid, powerful talk.
author: Carla Harris, TEDWomen 2018

title: Important Documents - Notary Questions and Protection of Providers
description:
Q: I have been trying to get my will, health care power of attorney and other documents notarized for the past 2 weeks. it seems all notaries in the system have been deemed non-essential and are home without any department willing to bring them in. it's actually caused more stress in my life than running the oncology services in a pandemic and talking to other front line providers I know I'm not alone. It would be great if the health system would deem this piece of self-care essential for those of us who need to protect our families. bringing someone in to notarize these documents for us would relieve a great deal of stress. I have been referred to a traveling notary 3 times by hospital personnel. They charge $150, I really am not interested in paying someone to take advantage of me right now. please help. 

A: Thank you so much for bringing this to our attention. Many, many thanks to Mona Matson and Lisa Bellini for helping us to create this "Notary Clinic." We will start at PCAM but expand as needed:

Location: Second floor of PCAM off the glass elevators. 
Hours: Monday April 6-Friday April 10, from 8-9 AM and 1-2 PM
You must bring your driver’s license. 
Only estate planning documents will be notarized ie wills, transfer of property related to estates etc.
author: Jody Foster & Aliza Narva

title: Wellfocused Podcast: Season 1, Episode 9 - Life on The Frontlines of COVID-19 (ft. Clare Bennett)
description: The Wellfocused Podcast welcomes Clare Bennett, a registered nurse from the University of Pennsylvania Health System for this episode. Clare and I discuss the trials and tribulations of life as a frontline nurse over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as how being mindful of your health and wellbeing is essential in times of need.
author: Mitchell Sherman

title: Mammobile - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
We believe the best outcomes happen when we come together and use each other's different experiences and skills to analyze and solve problems in health care. 

 We’re in Corporate Information Services (CORP IS), and we help design and manage the systems that allow our providers to do their work. Last fall, Penn Medicine partnered with Siemens to run a mobile mammography unit in North Philadelphia. We offered free mammograms to women who couldn’t easily visit a Penn Medicine facility, or who didn’t have health insurance. Getting the unit up and running required behind-the-scenes planning and coordination that few people saw, but that was essential to the success of the program.   

 Larry assembled a team from (CORP IS), including Steve and Tracy on the PennChart build, Jim on Clinical Imaging, and many others from Networking, Remote Sites Infrastructure, Desktop, and Enterprise User Desktop teams. Steve and Tracy built a workflow in PennChart, ensured that patients would not be billed for the free screenings, and assigned all patients to a clinical staff member to review their results. Jim collaborated with Siemens to create a plan to overcome the technical challenge of transmitting the radiology scans from the mobile unit to the Penn Medicine system where they would be reviewed by staff. Other team members came together to get the unit up and running and ready for patients.   

 Most of the people who came to us were walk-ups. One woman stopped by for a mammogram and then sent over several people from her church. Another woman in her 70s had her first baseline mammogram in the unit. She told us that she’d been scared to go to the doctor’s office for a mammogram in the past, but now she was relieved to get it done so easily, right in her neighborhood. She said she would tell her family members about breast cancer screenings and encourage them to get other preventive health care as well. We provided a total of 241 mammograms, with 78 percent having normal findings, and 22 percent needing additional imaging, which patients learned about in a call from a physician.   

 That’s why we do our work. It’s more than just the builds, and overcoming the technical challenges we face. It comes down to the result: helping our providers offer world-class care to patients who wouldn’t otherwise have access to it.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 2, Ep. 9 - Racial Disparities in Healthcare + The World (ft. Dr. Jaya Aysola)
description: Dr. Jaya Aysola, Assistant Dean of Inclusion and Diversity at the Perelman School of Medicine and Founder and Executive Director of Penn Medicine’s Center for Health Equity Advancement, joins The Wellfocused Podcast to discuss the current state of inclusion and diversity at Penn and in the country. We also touch on the differences the last year has made and where we would like to see things move in the future.
author: Mitchell Sherman

title: Lawrence Pratt and Marchant Johnson - - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
A calm voice is a good voice—you get more from people by being kind than being angry.  

I’m Lawrence Pratt, and my colleague Marchant Johnson and I are security guards at Penn Presbyterian Medical Center (PPMC). Recently, a young man came into the hospital in police custody. He was headed to another facility to get psychiatric support, but first, he needed to stay overnight with us. In the morning, he was very agitated and upset.  

I was the first person from Security to arrive at his room. He was standing up and raising his voice. I waited for a quiet moment, then I asked him the question I always start with: “How can I help you make your situation better?”  

He answered that he wanted to go home and rest. I said, “I understand. In order to do that, you need to calm down and allow our staff to treat you.” We kept talking, and he said he was hungry. I brought him a snack, and the nurse gave him the medication he needed.  

Once he was able to regain his composure, the patient sat on his bed and listened to what his provider was telling him about his care. Twenty minutes later, he was discharged from the hospital.  

Sometimes when people see my uniform, I can tell from their body language that their defenses are up. What Marchant and I try to do is show that we’re fair and understanding. We want to find out what that person needs, and how we can help them. I tell people that in order to get what you want; you may have to bend a little so that you can get what you need.  

Everyone is different, and everyone needs to be treated with respect and dignity. Marchant and I like to approach our work with kindness and an open mind. It allows us to connect to people, gain their trust, and help them get the care that they need.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Disenfranchised Grief in a Year of Pandemic Losses
description: COVID-19 has brought about many instances, from cancelled weddings to postponed family reunions, that result in grief that isn't routinely acknowledged: disenfranchised grief. This NY Times article discusses the legitimacy of grief surrounding smaller losses that don't always involve the loss of human life. Read more to learn about ways you can acknowledge this grief, validate your losses, and find the support and rituals to enable you to move forward.
author: Tara Parker-Pope

title: Intro to Mindfulness
description: This video is meant to help find some inner balance and calmness during this stressful time. While we are busy and stressed during this time, it’s important to take some time here and there to take 5 minutes to be mindful throughout the day. Mindfulness meditation or mindful practice helps us develop our awareness of each moment of life. Mindfulness allows us to let go of the thoughts that are in our minds and choose what we want to focus on without judgment.
author: Simcha Zevit

title: Anti-Racism Booklist for All Ages from the American Libraries
description: A selection of Adult Fiction and Non-fiction books and Youths of all ages. Also a list of Booklists and Book Links.
author: American Libraries

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 7 - Nuances of Anxiety (ft. Dr. Noelle Ciara)
description: Dr. Noelle Ciara joins The Wellfocused Podcast to discuss the ins and outs of anxiety. Here we take a deep dive into how anxiety has many definitions, strategies for coping, and how the stigma surrounding mental health has changed in recent years.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: Making Sense of Health Insurance
description:
Does reading a statement from your health insurance company feel like reading hieroglyphics to you?  In this episode, Erica Munger, MA, senior utilization management reviewer at Penn Medicine - Princeton House Behavioral Health sits down with Andy to discuss what to consider when selecting a health insurance plan.  Erica also explains how to make sense of health insurance premiums and deductibles.

 

For more information on Penn Medicine – Princeton House Behavioral Health:

Princeton House Behavioral Health (princetonhcs.org)

 

Follow us on Facebook!

facebook.com/princetonhousebh
author: Mind on Mental Health

title: Setting Boundaries around the Holidays
description: Feeling overwhelmed with responsibilities during the holiday season? You're not alone. In this podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for the Treatment and Study of Anxiety, presents the "DEAR MAN" skill. She will explain what this tool is and how to use it to effectively set boundaries and maximize your time and energy this holiday season.
author: Lily Brown, PhD

title: Medicare Information As a Response to Covid-19
description: Care for Excluded Inpatient Psychiatric Unit Patients in the Acute Care Unit of a HospitalCMS has determined it is appropriate to issue a blanket waiver to IPPS and other acute care hospitals with excluded distinct part inpatient psychiatric units that, as a result of the emergency, need to relocate inpatients from the excluded distinct part psychiatric unit to an acute care bed and unit. The hospital should continue to bill for inpatient psychiatric services under the inpatient psychiatric facility prospective payment system for such patients and annotate the medical record to indicate the patient is a psychiatric inpatient being cared for in an acute care bed because of capacity or other exigent circumstances related to the emergency. This waiver may be utilized where the hospital‰Ûªs acute care beds are appropriate for psychiatric patients and the staff and environment are conducive to safe care. For psychiatric patients, this includes assessment of the acute care bed and unit location to ensure those patients at risk of harm to self and others are safely cared for.
author: CMS: Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services

title: Donating Blood as Frontline Provider
description:
Q: As a healthcare worker currently working with CV-19 patients, I am not allowed to give blood as per the American Red Cross.  I know we are very active in taking care of this population, but I would like to contribute in another way.  Because so many people are staying home and we are likely to experience a blood shortage, is there any way to donate as an employee right now?
We are most grateful to Don L. Siegel, Ph.D., M.D., Professor of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Director, Division of Transfusion Medicine & Therapeutic Pathology for providing the content to answer this question:

A: The American Red Cross at its national level has added additional donor criteria to its questionnaire in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.  One of the new criteria which you may have encountered when speaking with the Red Cross or when completing their online day-of-collection screening tool is a disqualification if you “have cared for a patient with COVID-19”.  While we wait for clarification on what is meant by  “cared for”, at this point healthcare workers “working with CV-19 patients” probably meet this disqualification.  Though respiratory viruses, including corona viruses like the common cold, SARS and MERS, are not believed to be transmitted through transfusion because there has not been a case of them being transmitted through blood, the extensive panel of infectious disease tests donor blood undergoes does not include tests for these viruses and probably never will.  At this time, there is a theoretical concern by the Red Cross in transfusing blood components into patients that were collected from donors who might have some clinically inapparent level of COVID-19 viremia.  So, at this point there is no way to donate blood as an employee or otherwise.
 
However, clinical studies involving heath care workers are being launched at  Penn on HUP healthcare workers as well as on recovered patients to understand the basic virology and immune response to the virus.  You might have antibodies to the virus and never know that you were infected. The link for that set of studies is below.  There is also a convalescent plasma collection protocol for recovered patients that meet must meet certain FDA criteria.  The plasma will be transfused into the patients you are caring for at HUP.  The link for that is below as well.  But right now, to qualify, you must have had a positive COVID-19 test that is now negative and been 14 days symptom-free.  This criteria may change to simply having a negative COVID-19 test now and the presence of antibodies in your blood.  So, in the near future, you might qualify for that as well.
 
The one you can probably do now:
 
https://clinicalresearch.itmat.upenn.edu/clinicaltrial/6406/covid19-circulating-t-cell-subsets-in-peripheral-blood/?qd=1460747
 
The one you might be eventually able to do:
https://clinicalresearch.itmat.upenn.edu/clinicaltrial/6404/covid-19-covid19-coronavirus-plasma-donor-registry-for-patients-recovered-from-confirmed-covid19/?qd=1460747
author: Don Siegel, Ph.D., M.D.

title: Thank You
description: Students from the Perelman School of Medicine rally together to show support for our heroes on the front lines.
author: Students at the Perelman School of Medicine

title: Avoiding Burnout
description: During a pandemic, the jobs of health and safety workers become even more critical. As they put themselves in harm‰Ûªs way, we need to make sure we care for the caregivers. This piece is an excerpt from Adam Grant's WorkLife podcast it focuses on burnout and ways to combat these issues that we experience.
author: Adam Grant

title: Responding to Covid-19: Behavioral Health
description: How behavioral health systems are preparing to respond to what is the new normal. With these new guidelines in place they will serve as a basis for what is to come beyond this time when the pandemic is over.
author: Amanda Latimore Ph.D.

title: Coming Out of COVID-19: Preparing to Return to In-Person School and Activities
description: Although many of us have been looking forward to the end of the COVID-19 pandemic, returning to in-person activities after experiencing a year of social distancing can be stressful. This article shares insights and tips to support your child’s transition back to in-person activities.
author: Julia Martin Burch, PhD

title: MoodMission
description: When we feel down or anxious, there are heaps of things we can do to help us feel better again. Doing these things can help prevent everyday mood disturbances from developing into mental health issues, such as depression and anxiety disorders. When you tell MoodMission how you're feeling, it gives you a tailored list of 5 simple, quick, effective, evidence-based Missions to improve your mood. All Missions are taken from scientific research, made accessible to you through the app, so you can learn exactly how what you're doing is helping. Completing Missions earns you rewards in the app, motivating you to take steps towards becoming healthier, happier, and more confident.
author: David Bakker and Nikki Richard

title: Resilience Skills in a Time of Uncertainty
description: We all face unprecedented challenges and change as we navigate the COVID-19 pandemic. To support you in this time of uncertainty, the University of Pennsylvania is sharing a free and unique course in Resilience Skills, taught by Dr. Karen Reivich and adapted from the Foundations of Positive Psychology massive open online course (MOOC) series.
author: Karen Reivich, Ph.D.

title: How to Work from Home with your kids & Stay sane
description: Use image from article and credit: REUTERS/Lindsey WassonAcross the world, schools and daycare centers have closed their doors in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus. While this is incredibly important for the health of our communities, working parents face complex decisions about how to manage work and family demands. This article provides five tips for how to work from home with your kids around and stay sane.
author: Stewart Friedman & Alyssa Westring

title: Healthy Sleep Habits
description: Your daily routines – what you eat and drink, the medications you take, how you schedule your days and how you choose to spend your evenings – can significantly impact your quality of sleep. Even a few slight adjustments can, in some cases, mean the difference between sound sleep and a restless night.

title: Facing Burnout as a Healthcare Worker
description: Explanation of burnout and tips to combat it
author: Mental Health America

title: Building Resilience: How to Thrive During Challenging Times
description: Nano tools for building resilience during tough times. The goal from this exercise is to build resilience between yourself and your team, using the acronym of REAL: R = relationships, E: efficacy, A: (positive) affect), L: learning.
author: Katherine Klein, PhD, Edward H. Bowman Professor of Management; Vice Dean, Wharton Social Impact Initiative, The Wharton School

title: Mental Health & Coping Skills for Coronavirus
description: The Suicide Prevention Resource Center (SPRC) has compiled a selection of web pages and information sheets on mental health and coping with the effects of COVID-19. These resources are a selection from key organizations in the field. The audiences: general audience, mental health professionals, health care workers + first responders, community leaders, American Indians & Alaska Natives, Parents & Caregivers, and older adults.
author: Suicide Prevention Resource Center

title: Food Safety Tips
description: Practical tips for bringing grocery items into your home and storing them safely
author: Jeffrey VanWingen, MD

title: Finding Our Voice
description: Finding Our Voice brings the viewpoints and opinions of the next generation of psychiatrists – including residents, fellows, and early career psychiatrists – to the forefront. Each episode focuses on systemic racism within a racial, ethnic, or minority group. Listen as our host, Dr. Sanya Virani, leads discussions with guests who offer fresh perspectives on difficult issues by sharing their own stories and those of their patients. We hope you come away from each episode with new insights or a change of perspective. Finding Our Voice is a production of American Psychiatric Association Publishing and Psychiatric News.
author: Sanya Virani, M.D., American Psychiatric Association

title: Mourner's Bill of Rights
description: COVID Mourner's Bill of Rights
author: Dr. Alan Wolfelt

title: Tackling Burnout
description: Dr. Laura Hamill, Chief Science Officer at Limeade, will share the science behind burnout—including how to spot it, what the causes are, and how to prevent it. She will also share recent research conducted by Limeade Institute on how to use mindsets to handle stress, as well as talk about the important role organizations play in helping to prevent burnout.
author: Dr. Laura Hamill

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 2, Ep. 10 - Exercise and Motivation (ft. Dr. Alex Fanaroff)
description: Dr. Alex Fanaroff is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and is currently conducting a clinical trial regarding behavioral economics and exercise to combat cardiovascular disease. He joins the Wellfocused podcast to take a deep dive into this study and the different motivations to participate in and avoid exercise and how this can affect general health and well-being.
author: Mitchell Sherman

title: How to Handle Being Pregnant During COVID-19
description:
Q: Hello, I am a proud HUP nurse. I am pregnant (early in the second trimester) and very worried about working and contracting COVID-19. I have been trying to keep up to date on precautions for pregnant women and have been vigilant about hand washing and trying not to touch my face, get proper sleep/nutrition etc but I am scared for my baby. My pregnancy is considered high risk for other reasons and the only reassuring information I have seen comes from women who contracted the disease in their 3rd trimester and since I am only in the beginning of the second I am not sure what that means for my baby and me. I am also having a lot of anxiety thinking about needing to be in an ICU and what would happen to my baby. What if I am not able to be present for the birth or what if my baby gets sick too? What if I need to be separated from my baby after they are born? These thoughts bring me anxiety and sadness. I know my husband is also worried about me going to work and we are trying to stay safe but feel like this is out of our control. How can I best protect myself and my baby? Will someone advocate for me if I can't advocate for us?
A: We appreciate that working during this pandemic, particularly as we are still learning about the virus, can be very anxiety provoking and pregnant women have many important questions and concerns while navigating how to best protect themselves. I am attaching a FAQ for pregnant women that was developed in conjunction with OB/GYN, Pediatrics, and ID physicians at Penn and CHOP which can give you some further information.  I am also attaching Penn's guidance on working with COVID-19 infected patients for pregnant employees, and I would encourage you to have a dedicated discussion with your manager regarding your work environment and modifications made to keep you safe at this time. HR and Infection Control are also available to discuss with you at any time - and we really appreciate your dedication and want to keep you as safe as possible. Finally, if you're having trouble managing your anxiety, don't forget to consult the PennMedicineTogether website for the many resources now available to help you through it. FAQ for pregnant women: https://pennmedaccess.uphs.upenn.edu/f5-w-687474703a2f2f616363657373706f696e742e757068732e7570656e6e2e656475$$/sites/preparedness/coronavirus/Pages/f5-h-$$/sites/preparedness/coronavirus/Documents/AAP%20COVID%20Newborn%20FAQ%204.3.2020.docx?Web=1 Guidance for pregnant employees: https://pennmedaccess.uphs.upenn.edu/f5-w-687474703a2f2f616363657373706f696e742e757068732e7570656e6e2e656475$$/sites/preparedness/coronavirus/Pages/f5-h-$$/sites/preparedness/coronavirus/Documents/COVID-19-Guidelines-for-Pregnant-Older-Employees.pdf?Web=1
author: Aliza Narva & Jody Foster

title: Sleep Tips
description: Over the last year, the prevalence of sleep disorders and insomnia have increased tremendously. In this podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety, walks you through a few brief sleep tips. Dr. Brown shares evidence-based practices that you can use as first steps to tackle clinically significant insomnia. This podcast shares some great reminders for everyone who is trying to improve their sleep schedules and sleeping habits in the New Year.
author: Lily Brown, PhD

title: Managing Compassion Fatigue
description: We have been dipping extensively into our "wells of patience" for nearly two years. As the pandemic continues to take on new variations, you may be asked to make more sacrifices for the health of others, which may slowly be taking a toll on your mental health and well-being. In this 20-minute podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety, discusses the compassion fatigue feedback loop and how to manage your emotions, build relationships, and maintain your own peace of mind. Dr. Brown will walk through helpful steps to manage the intensity of your emotions and build energy and resilience.
author: Lily Brown, PhD

title: Advocate For Yourself During Stressful Times
description:
Q: I have in the past felt bullied by my supervisor and the stress of COVID has worsened these interactions. Currently I am being asked to take on new roles with which I have no prior experience and receiving no training or support. My past experiences with HR have been unhelpful. How can I advocate for myself (and my colleagues) with a difficult person during this stressful time?

A: Bullying is unacceptable now, as it is at any time. It is true that people are being asked to flexibly alter their roles as necessary, but it is also true that you should receive the necessary support to be able to do so. We will suggest that you approach your supervisor again and be clear that you are willing to take on new roles but that you need support in order to be able to do so (which ideally you can define for your supervisor). It may well be that your supervisor, who is stressed as we all are, is hearing your anxiety as reluctance or refusal and just getting more stressed or annoyed. If this does not do the trick then the next step remains HR and, if you take this route, we would again suggest that you be clear that you are willing to do alternate work but anxious and in need of training and support. And as always, if you feel bullied and hence unsafe, SafetyNet remains an available resource to make your concerns known.
author: Jody Foster & Aliza Narva

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 1 - Positive Psychology (ft. Luke Obermann)
description: Season 3 of the Wellfocused Podcast kicks off with Luke Obermann, a self-proclaimed "well-being nerd" who specializes in positive psychology. On this episode, we dive into the history and dynamics of positive psychology and how this can be implemented into everyday life in an individualized manner.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 2 - Making Wellbeing Work (ft. Dr. Lisa Bellini)
description: Dr. Lisa Bellini, Senior Vice Dean for Academic Affairs joins the Wellfocused Podcast to discuss some of the differences in wellbeing needs between clinical and non-clinical staff. We touch on physical, social, and cultural needs of various departments and how certain improvements can enhance the employee experience at UPHS.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 2, Ep. 6 - Toxic Positivity (ft. Emily McPeak)
description: Emily McPeak, Senior Work-life Consultant, is back as our first returning guest on The Wellfocused Podcast. Emily and I dive into the topic of toxic positivity. Sometimes, it is not always ideal to find the silver linings in tough situations. Here, we discuss the dynamics of toxic positivity and strategies to combat it to help pave your way to greater wellbeing.
author: Mitchell Sherman

title: Rebecca Boswell - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
At the launch of our Gender Talk series, attended by Penn Medicine providers and staff, I began the event by disclosing my own story. I shared that I’m a cis-gender white woman, and I have biases that come from the privileges my identity provides me. I said that I speak about gender diversity from a position of empathy, with an understanding of the science, but without lived experience. This leaves me with blind spots and room for growth. I hoped that by being open about my own perspective, our providers would feel like it’s okay to not be an expert, and would be more open to learning.  


 I developed the Gender Talk series because I want to educate our providers about gender identity and empower them to create a gender-affirming environment at work for each other and for our patients. I also wanted to model how we can acknowledge the limits of our understanding about what our patients have experienced in their lives.  

 What our providers need, in addition to research-supported information, is to hear from someone with lived experience. We invited Jillian Celentano, a transgender patient advocate and social worker, to join us as one of our featured speakers.  

 As Jillian has said, “I emphasize how important it is to talk about pronouns, to use the right terminology when speaking to trans and nonbinary patients. That makes all the difference to us.” Jillian also answered specific questions from providers, and told them how essential medical and mental health providers are in the community. “We can’t do this journey without you, but we’re also scared,” she added. Jillian shared how making small but important changes around how we interact with trans and nonbinary patients can make them feel much more comfortable in the health care setting.  

After our first Gender Talk series, I made sure that we were making those small but important changes, like having pronouns on our badges, correcting patients’ armband text, and introducing ourselves using our pronouns. Recently, I was talking to a patient who was very ill and had survived violence based on their gender identity. The patient pulled me aside and told me they didn’t usually feel safe in hospitals, but that the interactions with our staff felt positive. This made it possible for the patient to feel safe and respected.  

 Making progress in this area is very meaningful to the trans and nonbinary community. These steps we’re taking will go a long way towards achieving health equity, where every person seeking care is acknowledged, respected, and understood.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Nutrition Hacks for Your Mental Health
description: In this episode, registered dietitian Rachel Daddio sits down with Andy to discuss the connection between nutrition and mental health.  Rachel talks about different nutrition considerations she discusses with her clients at Penn Medicine – Princeton House Behavioral Health as well as how making different nutrition decisions can affect one’s mental health.
author: Mind on Mental Health

title: The Wellfocused Podcast: Sn. 3, Ep. 4 - Efficacy of Wrist-Worn Fitness Devices
description: In our first guest-less episode, I decided to analyze some research investigating how effective wrist-worn fitness devices (Fitbit, Apple Watch, etc.) are at measuring heart rate and calorie expenditure. Take a listen to determine if these devices are effective and how this information can be used to optimize your lifestyle habits as they pertain to exercise.
author: Mitch Sherman

title: Strengthen Your Immune System With 4 Simple Strategies
description: This article gives four simple and easy tips to boost your immune system.
author: Cleveland Clinic

title: Navigating Verbal Storms at a Primary Care Office
description: Jeffrey Howard Millstein, MD, a physician champion for patient experience at Penn Medicine, details how he approaches conversations about controversial topics with patients, from the political environment to mistrust in our country's health systems. He states, "by staying in my 'role,' leveraging curiosity, and working on setting the visit agenda, I’ve been able to reduce my stress level when patients interject controversial opinions during our visits."
author: Jeffrey Howard Millstein, MD

title: Preparing for a Disaster Part 1
description: There may be a calm in the storm of COVID-19, but we need to prep for future disasters. In this brief podcast, Dr. Lily Brown, Director of the Center for Treatment and Study of Anxiety, will discuss what you can do now to mentally prepare for future disasters (pandemic or otherwise). This is for anyone looking to improve their resilience and tackle any obstacles to come with a healthy mindset.
author: Lily Brown, PhD

title: Mary Dorman - PMX Week Stories of Cultural Humility
description:
Drawing a face on a piece of paper helped me see what I couldn’t see before.  

I coordinate Let’s Talk, Lancaster, a coalition of community partners dedicated to supporting mental health and wellness in our community. At one of our monthly workshops to advance trauma responsive practices, the facilitator took us through an exercise to help us reflect on our differences. We drew a circle on a piece of paper and then added a facial feature for every social connection we had with a person from a different background in our childhood.  

I looked down at the paper and saw one eye on an otherwise blank face. Seeing that image really struck me. I realized I can’t see what I haven’t lived.  

One way I can make a difference is to look at my sphere of influence, and make sure there are more seats at the table. Recently, we were reviewing a job description for a trauma-informed specialist position that required a bachelor’s degree, and I wondered if this degree was really needed for the work. After discussing it with the people who work closely with that position, we concluded that experience with trauma-informed care was just as important as having the degree.  

So we changed the job description to require either a bachelor’s degree or lived experience. That position could be filled by someone who may not have been considered before, who would bring a lot of experience into the room in addition to training. Someone who would help to broaden our lens as mental health care providers.  

I recognize now that lived experience informs so much of how we relate to one another. My role in community health is to pass the microphone and listen.
author: Penn Medicine Experience

title: Safety of Frontline Providers Around COVID-19 patients
description:
Q: I am very concerned about the change in policy regarding COVID positive patients. As a resident, I think it is very unsafe to be going in to speak and exam known covid positive patients with a surgical mask that is paper thin and for many of us, too large for our faces to the point where we feel air from the sides. As this is reported to be an airborne virus where particles remain in the air, I think it is unsafe and disrespectful to ask residents to take that risk when we have families at home who are prone to infection and are witnessing young patients like ourselves in the icu intubated. We have received emails about how many N95 donations we have received yet as the primary caretakers we are not seeing these masks and being told we are unable to obtain them when performing swabs, which per CDC guidelines is considered an aerosolizing procedure. I am overall disappointed and upset at the safety measures that have been put in place by penn medicine and hope that this is discussed in further detail. 


A: I appreciate your concerns about your safety while caring for COVID-19 patients. Based on the available data, we believe the virus is transmitted primarily through droplet route and contact of secretions with mucus membranes, with risk of airborne transmission only during aerosol generating procedures. In this setting, we are following the CDC and WHO guidance for contact, droplet, and eye protection during routine care of COVID-19 patients, and using respirators and PAPRs for aerosol generating procedures. We are prioritizing negative pressure rooms at present for critically ill patients and as many COVID patients as we can, and navigating increasing patient volumes. Our goal is to keep all of our staff safe, and provide respirators and PAPRs when the clinical situation necessitates risk of airborne transmission. We do not consider performing an NP swab to be an aerosol generating procedure based on available data, and feel that staff are safe performing this in gowns, gloves, face masks, and eye protection.  Face masks and eye protection will protect you from any droplet sized particles getting into your mouth, eyes, and nose.   We completely understand your concern about keeping your self and your family safe, and this is also our priority.  And we appreciate that our teams are working to take excellent care of our patients through a time of many unknowns.
author: Kathleen M Murphy, MD, Assistant Professor of Clinical Medicine, Division of Infectious Diseases
